script_text: <speak> Welcome to today's lesson — Greek & Latin Roots! Many English words come from Greek and Latin. If you know the ROOT — the base part — you can figure out words you've never seen before! It's like having a secret decoder ring for reading.<break time='1s'/> Let's get started!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Our next root is aud.. It comes from Latin and means hear. For example: audience, audio, auditorium..<break time='1s'/> An AUDience is a group that HEARS a performance!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Our next root is vis/vid.. It comes from Latin and means see. For example: visible, video, vision..<break time='1s'/> A VIDeo is something you SEE!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Our next root is scrib/script.. It comes from Latin and means write. For example: scribble, script, describe..<break time='1s'/> A SCRIPT is something WRITTEN for actors!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Our next root is port.. It comes from Latin and means carry. For example: transport, portable, export..<break time='1s'/> A PORTable device is easy to CARRY!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Our next root is graph.. It comes from Greek and means write/draw. For example: photograph, autograph, paragraph..<break time='1s'/> A photoGRAPH is light WRITING a picture!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Our next root is tele.. It comes from Greek and means far. For example: telephone, telescope, television..<break time='1s'/> A TELEphone lets you hear from FAR away!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>The root 'aud' means 'hear.' What is an auditorium?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> Does it mean... A place to eat? <break time='600ms'/> A place to hear performances? <break time='600ms'/> A place to swim? <break time='600ms'/> or A place to sleep? <break time=\'400ms\'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>The root 'vis' means 'see.' What does invisible mean?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> Does it mean... Very loud? <break time='600ms'/> Cannot be seen? <break time='600ms'/> Very large? <break time='600ms'/> or Cannot be heard? <break time=\'400ms\'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>The root 'port' means 'carry.' What does transport mean?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> Does it mean... To build something? <break time='600ms'/> To carry across? <break time='600ms'/> To break apart? <break time='600ms'/> or To write down? <break time=\'400ms\'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>The root 'graph' means 'write.' What is an autograph?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> Does it mean... A type of car? <break time='600ms'/> A person's own writing/signature? <break time='600ms'/> A kind of food? <break time='600ms'/> or A math problem? <break time=\'400ms\'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>The root 'tele' means 'far.' What does a telescope help you do?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> Does it mean... Hear far away? <break time='600ms'/> See far away? <break time='600ms'/> Travel far away? <break time='600ms'/> or Write far away? <break time=\'400ms\'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Think about the root word . <break time='500ms'/> what does it mean? Use that clue to figure out the answer!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a gentle, encouraging teacher:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Think about the root word . <break time='500ms'/> what does it mean? Use that clue to figure out the answer!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a gentle, encouraging teacher:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Think about the root word . <break time='500ms'/> what does it mean? Use that clue to figure out the answer!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a gentle, encouraging teacher:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Think about the root word . <break time='500ms'/> what does it mean? Use that clue to figure out the answer!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a gentle, encouraging teacher:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Think about the root word . <break time='500ms'/> what does it mean? Use that clue to figure out the answer!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a gentle, encouraging teacher:

script_text: <speak> The Word Detective Mia loved mysteries, and today she had a new one to solve — a page full of big words! Her teacher, Ms. Patel, wrote TELESCOPE on the board. 'I know tele means far,' Mia thought. 'And scope means to look. So a telescope helps you look far away!' Next was PORTABLE. 'Port means carry so portable means easy to carry!' Then came the hardest one: DESCRIBE. 'Hmm scrib means write,' Mia whispered. 'De means about. So describe means to write about something!' Ms. Patel smiled. 'Mia, you cracked the code.'.<break time='1s'/> 'Roots are like puzzle pieces,' Mia said. 'Once you know them, every big word is just a puzzle waiting to be solved.'</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading a story to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>How did Mia figure out the meaning of 'telescope'?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> Does it mean... She looked it up? <break time='600ms'/> She used the root words 'tele' and 'scope'? <break time='600ms'/> She asked her teacher? <break time='600ms'/> or She guessed? <break time=\'400ms\'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>What does the root 'scrib' mean?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> Does it mean... Read? <break time='600ms'/> Write? <break time='600ms'/> Speak? <break time='600ms'/> or Think? <break time=\'400ms\'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>What does Mia compare roots to?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> Building blocks? <break time='600ms'/> Puzzle pieces? <break time='600ms'/> Secret codes? <break time='600ms'/> or Keys? <break time=\'400ms\'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Welcome to today's lesson — Similes & Metaphors! Writers use comparisons to paint pictures with words! A SIMILE compares two things using 'like' or 'as.' A METAPHOR says something IS something else — no 'like' or 'as' needed. Both make writing more .. Let's get started!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Here's a simile: Her smile was as bright as the sun. Uses 'as.<break time='1s'/> as' to compare her smile to the sun</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Here's a simile: He ran like the wind..<break time='1s'/> Uses 'like' to compare his running to the wind</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Here's a metaphor: The classroom was a zoo..<break time='1s'/> Says the classroom IS a zoo — it was wild and noisy!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Here's a metaphor: Time is money..<break time='1s'/> Says time IS money — both are valuable and shouldn't be wasted</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Here's a simile: The stars twinkled like diamonds..<break time='1s'/> Uses 'like' to compare stars to sparkling diamonds</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Here's a metaphor: Her voice was velvet..<break time='1s'/> Says her voice IS velvet — it was smooth and soft</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>"The wind whispered through the trees." What type of figurative language is this?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> Simile? <break time='600ms'/> Metaphor? <break time='600ms'/> Personification? <break time='600ms'/> or Idiom? <break time=\'400ms\'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> "She ran as fast as a cheetah." This is an example of a Metaphor Simile Idiom.<break time='1s'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>or Hyperbole?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> "The snow was a white blanket over the town." This is a Simile Metaphor Personification.<break time='1s'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>or Alliteration?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> "His heart was as cold as ice." This is a Metaphor Simile Personification.<break time='1s'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>or Idiom?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> "Life is a roller coaster." This is a Simile Metaphor Idiom.<break time='1s'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>or Personification?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Remember, a simile uses 'like' or 'as.' A metaphor says something IS something else. Which one is this?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a gentle, encouraging teacher:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Listen to the question carefully and think about what you learned. You can do this!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a gentle, encouraging teacher:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Listen to the question carefully and think about what you learned. You can do this!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a gentle, encouraging teacher:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Listen to the question carefully and think about what you learned. You can do this!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a gentle, encouraging teacher:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Listen to the question carefully and think about what you learned. You can do this!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a gentle, encouraging teacher:

script_text: <speak> The Soccer Game The stadium was a roaring ocean of fans. Leo stepped onto the field, his legs shaking like leaves in a storm. The whistle blew, and the game was a blur of speed and sweat. Leo's teammate, Kai, was a rocket — he sprinted past every defender. Kai passed the ball to Leo. Time seemed to freeze. Leo kicked with everything he had. The ball flew like a bullet into the net! The crowd erupted. Their cheers were thunder rolling across the sky. Leo's smile was as wide as the goal itself..<break time='1s'/> 'We did it!' he shouted. His heart was a drum, beating fast with joy.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading a story to a student:

script_text: <speak> "The stadium was a roaring ocean of fans" is a Simile Metaphor Fact.<break time='1s'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>or Opinion?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Find the simile that describes Leo's legs. Shaking like leaves in a storm A roaring ocean A blur of speed.<break time='1s'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>or A drum beating fast?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> "Kai was a rocket" means Kai was On fire Very fast Very tall.<break time='1s'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>or Loud?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Welcome to today's lesson — Idioms & Proverbs! An IDIOM is a phrase that means something different from the actual words. 'Break a leg' doesn't mean hurt yourself — it means good luck! A PROVERB is a short, wise saying that teaches a lesson, like .. Let's get started!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The phrase is: break a leg. It means: Good luck!..<break time='1s'/> Said to performers before a show</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The phrase is: piece of cake. It means: Something very easy..<break time='1s'/> 'That test was a piece of cake!'</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The phrase is: hit the books. It means: To study hard..<break time='1s'/> 'I need to hit the books before the exam.'</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The phrase is: actions speak louder than words. It means: What you do matters more than what you say..<break time='1s'/> Show people through your behavior, not just promises</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The phrase is: don't judge a book by its cover. It means: Don't decide about something based on how it looks..<break time='1s'/> Get to know people before making judgments</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> The phrase is: the early bird catches the worm. It means: People who start early have an advantage..<break time='1s'/> Being on time and prepared pays off</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>What does the phrase "break a leg" mean?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> Does it mean... Actually break your leg? <break time='600ms'/> Good luck? <break time='600ms'/> Run fast? <break time='600ms'/> or Be careful? <break time=\'400ms\'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>"I'm feeling under the weather." What does this mean?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> Does it mean... Standing in rain? <break time='600ms'/> Feeling sick? <break time='600ms'/> Feeling happy? <break time='600ms'/> or Feeling cold? <break time=\'400ms\'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> "Don't cry over spilled milk" means Clean up your milk Don't be messy Don't worry about things you can't change.<break time='1s'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>or Milk is expensive?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> "The early bird catches the worm" teaches that Birds eat worms Starting early gives you an advantage Mornings are the best.<break time='1s'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>or Worms are hard to find?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> "She let the cat out of the bag" means she Released a cat Revealed a secret Opened a bag.<break time='1s'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>or Made a mess?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Think about what this phrase means in everyday language, not the literal words!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a gentle, encouraging teacher:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Listen to the question carefully and think about what you learned. You can do this!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a gentle, encouraging teacher:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Think about the root word . <break time='500ms'/> what does it mean? Use that clue to figure out the answer!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a gentle, encouraging teacher:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Listen to the question carefully and think about what you learned. You can do this!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a gentle, encouraging teacher:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Think about the root word . <break time='500ms'/> what does it mean? Use that clue to figure out the answer!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a gentle, encouraging teacher:

script_text: <speak> Grandma's Wisdom Every Saturday, Aisha visited her grandma..<break time='1s'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>'How was your week?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> ' Grandma asked? <break time='600ms'/> 'Terrible! I studied all week but still got a B on my test. It's not fair!'? <break time='600ms'/> Grandma smiled. 'Don't cry over spilled milk, sweetheart. A B is wonderful.'? <break time='600ms'/> 'But Maya didn't study at all and got an A!'? <break time='600ms'/> 'Don't judge a book by its cover,' Grandma said. 'Maybe Maya studied in ways you didn't see.'? <break time='600ms'/> Aisha sighed. 'I guess you're right.'? <break time='600ms'/> 'And remember — actions speak louder than words. Keep working hard, and your effort will pay off.'? <break time='600ms'/> or Aisha hugged her grandma. 'You always know what to say.'? <break time='600ms'/> 'That's because I've been around the block a few times!' Grandma laughed.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading a story to a student:

script_text: <speak> When Grandma says 'don't cry over spilled milk,' she means Don't make a mess Don't worry about what's already done Don't drink milk.<break time='1s'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>or Don't cry in public?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>What does 'been around the block' mean?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> Does it mean... Walked around the neighborhood? <break time='600ms'/> Has a lot of experience? <break time='600ms'/> Goes on walks? <break time='600ms'/> or Lives on a block? <break time=\'400ms\'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>What lesson does the proverb 'actions speak louder than words' teach Aisha?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> Talk less? <break time='600ms'/> Speak louder? <break time='600ms'/> Keep working hard and it will show? <break time='600ms'/> or Don't talk to Maya? <break time=\'400ms\'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Welcome to today's lesson — Text Structure! Authors organize their writing in different patterns called TEXT STRUCTURES. Knowing the structure helps you understand and remember what you read! Look for signal words — they're clues that tell you .. Let's get started!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Cause & Effect. Explains why something happened and what resulted.<break time='1s'/> Signal words include: because, so, therefore, as a result</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Compare & Contrast. Shows how two things are alike and different.<break time='1s'/> Signal words include: however, similarly, on the other hand, both</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Problem & Solution. Presents a problem and explains how it was solved.<break time='1s'/> Signal words include: the problem is, one solution, as a result, resolved by</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Chronological Order. Events told in the order they happened.<break time='1s'/> Signal words include: first, then, next, finally</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Description. Gives details about a topic using characteristics and examples.<break time='1s'/> Signal words include: for example, such as, including, characterized by</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>A passage that explains why something happened, and what resulted, uses which text structure?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> Compare & Contrast? <break time='600ms'/> Cause & Effect? <break time='600ms'/> Chronological Order? <break time='600ms'/> or Problem & Solution? <break time=\'400ms\'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which signal words tell you a passage is comparing two things?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> First, then, finally? <break time='600ms'/> Because, so, therefore? <break time='600ms'/> However, on the other hand, similarly? <break time='600ms'/> or Once upon a time? <break time=\'400ms\'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> "The city had too much traffic. To fix this, they built a new train system." This is Cause & Effect Compare & Contrast Problem & Solution.<break time='1s'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>or Description?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> "First, the settlers arrived. Then, they built homes. Finally, a town was formed." This is Compare & Contrast Cause & Effect Chronological Order.<break time='1s'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>or Problem & Solution?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> "Dogs are loyal and playful. Cats, however, tend to be more independent." This is Compare & Contrast Cause & Effect Chronological Order.<break time='1s'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>or Problem & Solution?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Look for signal words . <break time='500ms'/> they tell you how the author organized the information!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a gentle, encouraging teacher:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Look for signal words . <break time='500ms'/> they tell you how the author organized the information!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a gentle, encouraging teacher:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! A problem and solution text shows what went wrong and how it was fixed!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a gentle, encouraging teacher:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Words like 'first,' 'then,' and 'finally' mean things are told in time order!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a gentle, encouraging teacher:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Compare and contrast shows how things are alike AND different. Look for words like 'however' or 'similarly'!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a gentle, encouraging teacher:

script_text: <speak> Two Kinds of Energy There are two main kinds of energy that power our world: solar energy and fossil fuels. Solar energy comes from the sun. It is renewable, which means it won't run out. Solar panels collect sunlight and turn it into electricity. However, solar energy only works well on sunny days. Fossil fuels, on the other hand, come from deep underground. They include coal, oil, and natural gas. Fossil fuels are powerful and reliable, but burning them causes pollution. Both types of energy have advantages and disadvantages. Similarly, both play important roles in our daily lives..<break time='1s'/> Scientists are working to find the best balance between these energy sources to protect our planet while keeping the lights on.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading a story to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>What text structure does this passage mainly use?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> Chronological Order? <break time='600ms'/> Cause & Effect? <break time='600ms'/> Compare & Contrast? <break time='600ms'/> or Problem & Solution? <break time=\'400ms\'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which signal word helps you identify the structure?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> First? <break time='600ms'/> Because? <break time='600ms'/> On the other hand? <break time='600ms'/> or Finally? <break time=\'400ms\'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>What is one disadvantage of solar energy mentioned?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> It causes pollution? <break time='600ms'/> It costs too much? <break time='600ms'/> It only works well on sunny days? <break time='600ms'/> or It runs out quickly? <break time=\'400ms\'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Welcome to today's lesson — Finding the Theme! The THEME is the big message or lesson an author wants you to take away from a story. It's not the topic (what the story is about) — it's the deeper meaning. A story about a race might have the theme .. Let's get started!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Theme: Persistence pays off. A character keeps trying and eventually succeeds.<break time='1s'/> Look for characters who don't give up</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Theme: Be true to yourself. A character learns to be honest about who they are.<break time='1s'/> Look for characters who stop pretending</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Theme: Friendship matters. Characters help each other through hard times.<break time='1s'/> Look for how friends support one another</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Theme: Kindness makes a difference. A small act of kindness changes someone's day.<break time='1s'/> Look for the ripple effect of nice actions</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Theme: Don't judge by appearances. Someone surprising turns out to be helpful or talented.<break time='1s'/> Look for characters who prove others wrong</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Maya practiced piano every day after school. Some days she wanted to quit, but she kept going. At the spring recital, she played her piece perfectly. The audience gave her a standing ovation. What is the theme?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> Music is fun? <break time='600ms'/> Persistence leads to success? <break time='600ms'/> School is important? <break time='600ms'/> or Audiences are kind? <break time=\'400ms\'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Jake made fun of the new kid's old shoes. Later, the new kid shared his lunch when Jake forgot his. Jake felt terrible and apologized. They became best friends. What is the theme?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> Always bring lunch? <break time='600ms'/> New shoes are important? <break time='600ms'/> Don't judge others by their appearance? <break time='600ms'/> or Making fun is okay? <break time=\'400ms\'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Everyone told Rosa she was too small to play basketball. She practiced every day, and by the end of the season, she was the team's best shooter. What is the theme?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> Basketball is the best sport? <break time='600ms'/> Tall people are better at sports? <break time='600ms'/> Believe in yourself and work hard? <break time='600ms'/> or Practice is boring? <break time=\'400ms\'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Sam wanted to win the science fair alone. But his project kept failing. When he finally asked his classmates for help, they built something amazing together. What is the theme?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> Science is hard? <break time='600ms'/> Working together can achieve great things? <break time='600ms'/> Winning is everything? <break time='600ms'/> or Don't ask for help? <break time=\'400ms\'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Lily found a wallet full of money. Nobody was watching. She could have kept it, but she turned it in to the office. The owner was so grateful, she gave Lily a reward. What is the theme?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> Money is important? <break time='600ms'/> Finders keepers? <break time='600ms'/> Honesty is rewarded? <break time='600ms'/> or Always check the lost and found? <break time=\'400ms\'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Think about what the character learned. The theme is the big lesson or message!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a gentle, encouraging teacher:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Think about what the character learned. The theme is the big lesson or message!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a gentle, encouraging teacher:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Think about what the character learned. The theme is the big lesson or message!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a gentle, encouraging teacher:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Think about what the character learned. The theme is the big lesson or message!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a gentle, encouraging teacher:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Think about what the character learned. The theme is the big lesson or message!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a gentle, encouraging teacher:

script_text: <speak> The Art Contest Zara wanted to win the school art contest more than anything. She spent weeks painting a sunset, using every color she had. On the day of the contest, she saw the other entries. They were incredible. 'I'll never win,' she whispered. But when she looked at her painting again, she noticed something. The colors blended perfectly. The sky glowed. It was HER sunset, painted HER way. The judges announced third place, then second place. Neither was Zara. 'And first place goes to Zara Chen!' Zara couldn't believe it. Her eyes filled with happy tears..<break time='1s'/> Her teacher said, 'You won because you painted from your heart, not from someone else's.'</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading a story to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>What is the theme of this story?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> Art contests are stressful? <break time='600ms'/> Being yourself leads to success? <break time='600ms'/> Sunsets are beautiful? <break time='600ms'/> or Teachers are always right? <break time=\'400ms\'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>What almost made Zara give up?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> She ran out of paint? <break time='600ms'/> She saw how good the other entries were? <break time='600ms'/> Her teacher criticized her? <break time='600ms'/> or She was late? <break time=\'400ms\'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>What does the teacher mean by 'painted from your heart'?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> Does it mean... She used red paint? <break time='600ms'/> She was being authentically herself? <break time='600ms'/> She painted a heart? <break time='600ms'/> or She was emotional? <break time=\'400ms\'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Welcome to today's lesson — Point of View! Every story is told from a POINT OF VIEW. FIRST PERSON means a character in the story is telling it — they use 'I' and 'me.' THIRD PERSON means someone outside the story is telling it — they use 'he,'.. Let's get started!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> First Person. Uses pronouns like: I, me, my I walked to school and saw my friend waiting for me..<break time='1s'/> You know exactly what the narrator thinks and feels</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Third Person Limited. Uses pronouns like: he, she, they She walked to school. She felt nervous about the test..<break time='1s'/> You know one character's thoughts and feelings</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Third Person Omniscient. Uses pronouns like: he, she, they She felt nervous. He felt excited. They both wanted to win..<break time='1s'/> You know what ALL characters think and feel</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>"I couldn't believe my eyes when the dolphin jumped right next to our boat!" What point of view?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> First person? <break time='600ms'/> Third person limited? <break time='600ms'/> Third person omniscient? <break time='600ms'/> or Second person? <break time=\'400ms\'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>"Marcus sprinted down the field. His heart pounded as he neared the goal." What point of view?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> First person? <break time='600ms'/> Third person limited? <break time='600ms'/> Second person? <break time='600ms'/> or No point of view? <break time=\'400ms\'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which word is a clue that a story is in first person?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> He? <break time='600ms'/> She? <break time='600ms'/> I? <break time='600ms'/> or They? <break time=\'400ms\'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>"Anna felt worried. Across town, her brother felt the same way, though neither knew it." What point of view?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> First person? <break time='600ms'/> Third person limited? <break time='600ms'/> Third person omniscient? <break time='600ms'/> or Second person? <break time=\'400ms\'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Why might an author choose first person?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> To describe every character equally? <break time='600ms'/> To make the reader feel close to one character? <break time='600ms'/> To hide all characters' feelings? <break time='600ms'/> or To make the story shorter? <break time=\'400ms\'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Listen to the pronouns. 'I' and 'me' mean first person. 'He' and 'she' mean third person!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a gentle, encouraging teacher:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Listen to the pronouns. 'I' and 'me' mean first person. 'He' and 'she' mean third person!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a gentle, encouraging teacher:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Listen to the pronouns. 'I' and 'me' mean first person. 'He' and 'she' mean third person!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a gentle, encouraging teacher:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Listen to the pronouns. 'I' and 'me' mean first person. 'He' and 'she' mean third person!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a gentle, encouraging teacher:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Listen to the pronouns. 'I' and 'me' mean first person. 'He' and 'she' mean third person!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a gentle, encouraging teacher:

script_text: <speak> Two Sides of the Story VERSION 1 — FIRST PERSON: I stared at the last cookie on the plate. My mouth watered. I reached for it slowly but my sister's hand shot out and grabbed it first! 'Hey! That was mine!' I yelled. She just laughed and took a big bite. I couldn't believe it. That was SO unfair. VERSION 2 — THIRD PERSON: Oliver stared at the last cookie. His mouth watered as he reached for it. But Emma was faster. She snatched it with a grin. 'Hey! That was mine!' Oliver yelled..<break time='1s'/> Emma laughed. She didn't think it was unfair at all — after all, she had baked the cookies herself.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading a story to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Version 1 is written in which point of view?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> First person? <break time='600ms'/> Third person limited? <break time='600ms'/> Third person omniscient? <break time='600ms'/> or Second person? <break time=\'400ms\'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>In Version 2, what extra information do we learn?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> Oliver baked the cookies? <break time='600ms'/> Emma baked the cookies? <break time='600ms'/> Mom baked the cookies? <break time='600ms'/> or Nobody baked them? <break time=\'400ms\'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Why does Version 1 feel more personal?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> It's longer? <break time='600ms'/> We hear the narrator's exact thoughts and feelings? <break time='600ms'/> It has more characters? <break time='600ms'/> or It's funnier? <break time=\'400ms\'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Welcome to today's lesson — Author's Purpose! Every author writes for a reason — their PURPOSE. The three main purposes are: INFORM (teach you facts), PERSUADE (convince you of something), and ENTERTAIN (tell you an enjoyable story). Some texts d.. Let's get started!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Inform. Teaches facts, explains how something works, or gives information.<break time='1s'/> Example: Dolphins are mammals that live in the ocean.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Persuade. Tries to convince you to think or do something.<break time='1s'/> Example: Everyone should recycle — our planet depends on it!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Entertain. Tells a story or makes you laugh, feel, or imagine.<break time='1s'/> Example: The dragon sneezed, and the whole village lost its eyebrows.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> "The ancient Egyptians built the pyramids as tombs for their pharaohs. These massive structures took thousands of workers and many years to complete." The author's purpose is to Persuade you to visit Egypt Inform you about the pyramids Entertain with a story.<break time='1s'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>or Compare buildings?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> "School lunches should include more fresh fruits and vegetables. Studies show that healthy food helps students focus and learn better." The author's purpose is to Entertain Inform Persuade.<break time='1s'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>or Describe?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> "Captain Whiskers leaped from rooftop to rooftop, her cape flapping in the moonlight. The city's mice didn't stand a chance!" The author's purpose is to Inform Persuade Entertain.<break time='1s'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>or Argue?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>How can you tell when an author is trying to PERSUADE you?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> They use only facts? <break time='600ms'/> They use opinions and emotional language? <break time='600ms'/> They tell a funny story? <break time='600ms'/> or They describe a place? <break time=\'400ms\'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> "Coral reefs are sometimes called the rainforests of the sea. They support more species per unit area than any other marine environment. Yet coral reefs are threatened by rising ocean temperatures." The author's purpose is to Entertain with a fish story Persuade you to go diving Inform about coral reefs and their challenges.<break time='1s'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>or Compare forests and oceans?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Ask yourself . <break time='500ms'/> is the author trying to teach facts, convince you of something, or tell a fun story?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a gentle, encouraging teacher:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Ask yourself . <break time='500ms'/> is the author trying to teach facts, convince you of something, or tell a fun story?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a gentle, encouraging teacher:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Ask yourself . <break time='500ms'/> is the author trying to teach facts, convince you of something, or tell a fun story?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a gentle, encouraging teacher:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Ask yourself . <break time='500ms'/> is the author trying to teach facts, convince you of something, or tell a fun story?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a gentle, encouraging teacher:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Ask yourself . <break time='500ms'/> is the author trying to teach facts, convince you of something, or tell a fun story?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a gentle, encouraging teacher:

script_text: <speak> Save the School Garden! Our school garden is in danger. The district wants to pave it over for a new parking lot. But this garden is more than just plants. It's a classroom. In science, we studied how seeds grow into vegetables. In math, we measured garden beds and calculated soil needs. In art, we sketched the sunflowers. Studies show that school gardens improve student test scores by up to fifteen percent. Students who work in gardens also show better attendance and behavior. Other schools that lost their gardens regretted it. Jefferson Elementary paved their garden three years ago, and students there miss it every day..<break time='1s'/> We can save our garden. Come to the school board meeting Tuesday night. Bring a sign. Bring your voice. Our garden — and our learning — depends on it.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading a story to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>What is the author's main purpose?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> To entertain with a garden story? <break time='600ms'/> To inform about how plants grow? <break time='600ms'/> To persuade readers to save the school garden? <break time='600ms'/> or To describe what a garden looks like? <break time=\'400ms\'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>What evidence does the author use to support their argument?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> A funny joke? <break time='600ms'/> Test score data and examples from other schools? <break time='600ms'/> A recipe for vegetables? <break time='600ms'/> or A poem about flowers? <break time=\'400ms\'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> "Come to the school board meeting" is an example of A fact A call to action A description.<break time='1s'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>or A metaphor?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Welcome to today's lesson . <break time='500ms'/> Context Clues & Vocabulary! When you find a word you don't know, don't panic! Listen to the CONTEXT . <break time='500ms'/> the words and sentences around it. Authors often give clues: they might define the word, give an example, use a synonym, or show.. Let's get started!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Definition Clue. The author defines the word right in the sentence.<break time='1s'/> Example: The arid, or very dry, desert stretched for miles.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Example Clue. The author gives examples to explain the word.<break time='1s'/> Example: Nocturnal animals, such as owls, bats, and raccoons, are active at night.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Synonym Clue. A word with a similar meaning appears nearby.<break time='1s'/> Example: The enormous elephant was the biggest animal at the zoo.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Contrast Clue. ... The opposite meaning is given as a hint ... Example: Unlike her timid sister, Ava was bold and fearless.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>"The dog was so famished after the long hike that it devoured its entire bowl of food in seconds." What does famished most likely mean?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> Does it mean... Tired? <break time='600ms'/> Very hungry? <break time='600ms'/> Excited? <break time='600ms'/> or Thirsty? <break time=\'400ms\'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>"The ancient ruins were dilapidated — the walls crumbled and the roof had caved in long ago." What does dilapidated mean?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> Does it mean... Beautiful? <break time='600ms'/> New? <break time='600ms'/> Fallen apart and ruined? <break time='600ms'/> or Painted? <break time=\'400ms\'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>"Unlike the boisterous crowd at the game, the library was tranquil and silent." What does tranquil mean?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> Does it mean... Loud? <break time='600ms'/> Calm and peaceful? <break time='600ms'/> Empty? <break time='600ms'/> or Dark? <break time=\'400ms\'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> "Reptiles, such as snakes, lizards, and turtles, are cold-blooded animals." The examples help you understand that reptiles are Mammals Birds A group including snakes, lizards, and turtles.<break time='1s'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>or Fish?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>"The scientist made a remarkable discovery — something so extraordinary that it changed the field forever." What does remarkable mean?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> Does it mean... Boring? <break time='600ms'/> Small? <break time='600ms'/> Amazing and noteworthy? <break time='600ms'/> or Confusing? <break time=\'400ms\'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Listen to the words around the unknown word . <break time='500ms'/> they give you clues about its meaning!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a gentle, encouraging teacher:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Listen to the words around the unknown word . <break time='500ms'/> they give you clues about its meaning!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a gentle, encouraging teacher:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Listen to the words around the unknown word . <break time='500ms'/> they give you clues about its meaning!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a gentle, encouraging teacher:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! The examples after 'such as' tell you exactly what reptiles are!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a gentle, encouraging teacher:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Listen to the words around the unknown word . <break time='500ms'/> they give you clues about its meaning!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a gentle, encouraging teacher:

script_text: <speak> The Mysterious Museum On the field trip, Dante stopped in front of a strange artifact — an ancient object behind thick glass. The plaque read: 'This relic, found in the ruins of a forgotten city, is estimated to be over 3,000 years old.'.<break time='1s'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>'What's an artifact?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> ' asked his friend Priya? <break time='600ms'/> 'It's an object from a long time ago,' Dante said, pointing to the old pottery and tools nearby? <break time='600ms'/> They moved to the next room, where the air felt frigid — completely opposite of the warm hallway they'd just left? <break time='600ms'/> 'This room preserves delicate items,' the guide explained. 'The cold temperature prevents deterioration — that means it stops things from breaking down over time.'? <break time='600ms'/> or 'Context clues!' Priya whispered. 'The guide just defined deterioration for us.'? <break time='600ms'/> Dante grinned. 'Reading skills work in real life too.'</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading a story to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>What context clue helps you understand 'artifact'?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> The glass case? <break time='600ms'/> The nearby pottery and tools as examples? <break time='600ms'/> The room temperature? <break time='600ms'/> or The plaque color? <break time=\'400ms\'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>What does 'frigid' mean based on context?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> Does it mean... Very warm? <break time='600ms'/> Very cold? <break time='600ms'/> Very dark? <break time='600ms'/> or Very large? <break time=\'400ms\'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>How does the guide help readers understand 'deterioration'?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> By giving an example? <break time='600ms'/> By showing a contrast? <break time='600ms'/> By defining it directly? <break time='600ms'/> or By using a synonym? <break time=\'400ms\'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Welcome to today's lesson — Character Analysis! Good readers don't just know WHAT characters do — they understand WHY. You can learn about a character by paying attention to three things: what they THINK (their inner feelings), what they SAY (their.. Let's get started!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Thoughts. What the character thinks or feels inside Example: 'I hope nobody notices I'm nervous,' she thought..<break time='1s'/> This reveals: She's self-conscious and anxious</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Words. What the character says out loud Example: 'Don't worry, I'll help you carry those,' he said..<break time='1s'/> This reveals: He's kind and helpful</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Actions. What the character does Example: She stayed late every night to practice her lines..<break time='1s'/> This reveals: She's dedicated and hardworking</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Reactions. How the character responds to events Example: When he lost the game, he congratulated the winner..<break time='1s'/> This reveals: He's a good sport with strong character</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>"Even though Carlos was exhausted, he stayed to help his teammates clean up after practice." What does this tell you about Carlos?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> He's lazy? <break time='600ms'/> He's selfish? <break time='600ms'/> He's loyal and hardworking? <break time='600ms'/> or He's angry? <break time=\'400ms\'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>"'I'm sure you'll do great,' said Nina, even though she secretly hoped she would score higher." What does this reveal about Nina?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> She's completely honest? <break time='600ms'/> She says nice things but is competitive inside? <break time='600ms'/> She doesn't care about scores? <break time='600ms'/> or She's a bad friend? <break time=\'400ms\'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> "When the younger kids were being bullied, Tomas stepped between them and said, 'Leave them alone.'" This shows Tomas is Scared A bully Brave and protective.<break time='1s'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>or Shy?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which of these reveals the MOST about a character?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> What they look like? <break time='600ms'/> What they eat? <break time='600ms'/> What they do when nobody is watching? <break time='600ms'/> or What they wear? <break time=\'400ms\'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> "Grace frowned at her test score. She immediately opened her textbook and started reviewing her mistakes." Grace is Giving up Determined to improve Angry at her teacher.<break time='1s'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>or Bored?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Think about what the character thinks, says, and does. Those are clues about who they really are!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a gentle, encouraging teacher:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Think about what the character thinks, says, and does. Those are clues about who they really are!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a gentle, encouraging teacher:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Think about what the character thinks, says, and does. Those are clues about who they really are!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a gentle, encouraging teacher:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Think about what the character thinks, says, and does. Those are clues about who they really are!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a gentle, encouraging teacher:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! Think about what the character thinks, says, and does. Those are clues about who they really are!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a gentle, encouraging teacher:

script_text: <speak> The New Student Everyone ignored the new girl, Hana, on her first day. At lunch, she sat alone. She opened her notebook and started drawing — detailed sketches of birds that looked almost real. Jackson noticed from across the cafeteria. 'Those drawings are incredible,' he thought. But his friends were watching, and being nice to the new kid wasn't cool. Jackson looked at his friends. Then he looked at Hana, sitting alone..<break time='1s'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>He picked up his tray and walked over. 'Mind if I sit here?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> I'm Jackson.'? <break time='600ms'/> Hana looked up, surprised. 'I'm Hana. Sure!'? <break time='600ms'/> 'Your drawings are amazing,' Jackson said? <break time='600ms'/> or His friends stared from across the room. But Jackson didn't care? <break time='600ms'/> Sometimes doing the right thing means standing alone — or in this case, sitting with someone who is.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading a story to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>What do Jackson's ACTIONS reveal about his character?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> He follows the crowd? <break time='600ms'/> He's brave enough to do what's right even when it's not popular? <break time='600ms'/> He doesn't like his friends? <break time='600ms'/> or He wants Hana to draw him? <break time=\'400ms\'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>What internal conflict does Jackson face?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> He's hungry? <break time='600ms'/> He wants to sit with his friends but also wants to be kind to Hana? <break time='600ms'/> He doesn't like drawing? <break time='600ms'/> or He's new too? <break time=\'400ms\'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>How does Hana's drawing reveal something about her character?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> She's messy? <break time='600ms'/> She's talented and uses art to cope with being alone? <break time='600ms'/> She doesn't like school? <break time='600ms'/> or She wants attention? <break time=\'400ms\'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Welcome to today's lesson — Summarizing! A SUMMARY is a short retelling of the most important information. It includes only the key details — not every little thing. For stories, include: WHO (main character), WHAT (the problem), HOW (how it.. Let's get started!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Who. The main character or subject.<break time='1s'/> Who is the story/article about?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> What. The main problem, event, or topic.<break time='1s'/> What happened or what is the main idea?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> How. How it was resolved or explained.<break time='1s'/> How was it solved? What supports the main idea?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> Why. The lesson, theme, or significance.<break time='1s'/> Why does this matter?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> A summary should include Every detail from the story Only the most important information Your personal opinion.<break time='1s'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>or Only the funny parts?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>"Tom forgot his homework. His teacher gave him extra time. He finished it at lunch. He got an A." Which is the best summary?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> Tom went to school? <break time='600ms'/> Tom forgot his homework but his teacher gave him extra time and he finished it? <break time='600ms'/> Tom got an A on everything? <break time='600ms'/> or Tom ate lunch at school? <break time=\'400ms\'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which detail would you LEAVE OUT of a summary about a girl winning a spelling bee?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> She practiced every night? <break time='600ms'/> She won first place? <break time='600ms'/> She wore a blue shirt? <break time='600ms'/> or The final word was 'magnificent'? <break time=\'400ms\'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> When summarizing informational text, you should include The main idea and key supporting details Every sentence from the text Only the first paragraph.<break time='1s'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>or Your opinion about the topic?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> A good summary is Longer than the original The same length as the original Shorter than the original.<break time='1s'/> <emphasis level='moderate'>or Exactly the same words?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! A good summary only includes the most important information. Leave out the small details!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a gentle, encouraging teacher:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! A good summary only includes the most important information. Leave out the small details!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a gentle, encouraging teacher:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! A good summary only includes the most important information. Leave out the small details!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a gentle, encouraging teacher:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! For informational text, focus on the main idea and the facts that support it!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a gentle, encouraging teacher:

script_text: <speak>Here's a hint! A good summary only includes the most important information. Leave out the small details!</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a gentle, encouraging teacher:

script_text: <speak> The Great Migration Every year, millions of monarch butterflies make an incredible journey. They travel up to 3,000 miles from Canada and the United States to the mountains of central Mexico. This trip is called the Great Migration. It is one of the most amazing events in nature. The butterflies fly south to escape the cold winter. They gather in forests where the temperature is just right — not too hot and not too cold. Scientists are still learning how monarchs navigate such huge distances. Some believe they use the sun as a compass. Others think they may sense Earth's magnetic field..<break time='1s'/> Sadly, monarch populations have been declining. Loss of habitat and changes in climate threaten their survival. Conservation groups are working to plant milkweed — the only plant where monarchs lay their eggs — to help save these remarkable insects.</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading a story to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>What is the main idea of this passage?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> Butterflies are pretty? <break time='600ms'/> Monarch butterflies make an amazing migration but face threats? <break time='600ms'/> Scientists study insects? <break time='600ms'/> or Mexico has nice weather? <break time=\'400ms\'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which is the best summary of this passage?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> Butterflies fly south and scientists study them? <break time='600ms'/> Monarch butterflies travel 3,000 miles from North America to Mexico each year to escape winter, but their population is declining due to habitat loss, so conservation groups are planting milkweed to help? <break time='600ms'/> Butterflies like milkweed and warm weather? <break time='600ms'/> or Scientists think butterflies use the sun? <break time=\'400ms\'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:

script_text: <speak> <emphasis level='moderate'>Which detail is important enough to include in a summary?</emphasis><break time='800ms'/> The temperature is just right? <break time='600ms'/> They travel up to 3,000 miles? <break time='600ms'/> Some scientists study the sun? <break time='600ms'/> or The forests are in mountains? <break time=\'400ms\'/> What do you think?</speak>
voice_direction: Read this like a friendly, clear teacher reading to a student:
